anchor.surface_text: Whether the disallowance of Rs. 50,000 was a valid deduction from expenditure under section 10 of the Act ? The Tribunal then stated a case, and by its judgment and order dated February 24, 1955, the High Court answered the first two questions against the assessee and the third question being companysequently was also answered against the assessee. The assessee companypany then asked for and obtained special leave from this companyrt and the present appeal has been filed in pursuance of leave granted by this Court.

issues.text: Whether there was any material before the Tribunal for the finding that the wages had been inflated?

anchor.surface_text: As in the High Court so also before us, the short questions is whether there was any material before the Tribunal for the finding that the wages had been inflated. If there was such material from which a reasonable inference as to inflation of wages companyld be drawn, the matter is at an end. Having heard learned companynsel for the appellant, we agree with the view expressed by the High Court that there was such material.

holdings.text: There was material before the Tribunal from which a reasonable inference as to inflation of wages could be drawn

anchor.surface_text: As in the High Court so also before us, the short questions is whether there was any material before the Tribunal for the finding that the wages had been inflated. If there was such material from which a reasonable inference as to inflation of wages could be drawn, the matter is at an end. Having heard learned counsel for the appellant, we agree with the view expressed by the High Court that there was such material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defects in acquittance rolls, failure to produce comparative salary statements, and rejection of assessee's explanations provide material permitting reasonable inference of inflation despite some accepted explanations.

holdings.text: The non-acceptance of assessee's explanations does not convert the finding of wage inflation, which is a question of fact, into a question of law

anchor.surface_text: Whether these explanations are correct or no do not fall for decision at this stage. It was for the income-tax authorities chose no to accept these explanations as correct, that does no mean that the finding as to inflation of wages at which they arrived was a finding based on no material. The materials were there what happened what that the income-tax authorities did no accept as correct the explanations offered by the assessee company. We do no think that the no-acceptance of the explanations given by the assessee company converts the question of the inflation of wages, which is essentially a question of fact, into a question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presence of material supports Tribunal's factual finding even if explanations rejected; courts do not re-appraise facts.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in its answer to the first question

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, right in its answer to this first question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement with High Court's conclusion based on material reviewed.

holdings.text: Assessee cannot complain of no opportunity under section 23(3) as it produced materials in response to notices and authorities considered explanations

anchor.surface_text: As to the second argument we do no think that the assessee company can make any grievance on the score that no opportunity was given to it as contemplated by section 23 3 of the Act. The assessee company did no produce the comparative statement asked for by the Income-tax Officer. It filed a statement showing increased rates of salary which was of no help. It then produced the acquittance rolls of workmen on monthly wages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee responded to notices with materials and explanations which were considered at all levels; no fresh opportunity needed for each reason in final order.

holdings.text: Section 23(3) does not require opportunity to produce fresh evidence or explanation for every reason formulated in the assessment order

anchor.surface_text: Section 23 3 does no contemplate that with regard to every reason which the Income-tax Officer formulates for his order, the assessee must be given an opportunity to produce fresh evidence or fresh explanation. The Income-tax Officer fully considered whatever materials the assessee company produced in reply to the notices issued to it or even independently of that notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision requires general opportunity before order, satisfied by notices and consideration of produced materials.

holdings.text: Tribunal's finding confirms opportunities were given and supports inference of inflation justifying Rs. 50,000 addition

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, the Tribunal accepted some of the explanations as good explanations yet the Tribunal found that the defects in the keeping of acquittance rolls or the wages record indicated an inflation of wages and held that the Income-tax Officer was right in adding back Rs. 50,000 in respect thereof. This finding of the Tribunal can have only one meaning, namely, that there was an inflation of wages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal accepted some explanations but still found defects justified addition based on material.

holdings.text: High Court rightly answered the questions referred including validity of disallowance under section 10
holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement with High Court on all referred questions consequent to findings on material and procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, the Tribunal accepted some of the explanations as good explanations yet the Tribunal found that the defects in the keeping of acquittance rolls or the wages record indicated an inflation of wages and held that the Income-tax Officer was right in adding back Rs. 50,000 in respect thereof. This finding of the Tribunal can have only one meaning, namely, that there was an inflation of wages.
